steps.text: Ensure scene safety: Put on gloves if available. Call 911 immediately - severe bleeding is life-threatening
Expose the wound: Remove or cut away clothing to clearly see injury. Identify the source of bleeding
Apply direct pressure: Use clean cloth, gauze, or clothing. Press firmly with both hands directly on the wound. Do not let go
Pack deep wounds: For large or deep wounds, stuff clean cloth into wound while maintaining pressure. This is called wound packing
If blood soaks through: Do NOT remove first dressing. Add more layers on top and increase pressure. Removing disturbs clotting
Consider tourniquet for limb wounds: Apply 2-3 inches above wound, not on joint. Tighten until bleeding stops. Note the time applied
Position victim: Keep them lying down. Elevate legs if no spinal injury suspected. Keep them warm with blankets
Monitor for shock: Watch for pale skin, rapid pulse, confusion, anxiety. These indicate significant blood loss requiring immediate transport

name: Minor Bleeding
description: Small cuts and scrapes requiring basic first aid

steps.text: Wash hands before treating wound
Clean wound gently with clean water
Apply gentle pressure with clean cloth
Apply antibiotic ointment if available
Cover with sterile bandage
Change bandage daily and watch for infection
Have person sit upright and lean slightly forward
Pinch soft part of nose firmly
Hold for 10-15 minutes without releasing
Apply cold compress to bridge of nose
Seek medical help if bleeding persists beyond 20 minutes
Do not blow nose or pick at clot for several hours
Assess the injury: Look for deformity, swelling, bruising, or bone protruding through skin (open fracture). Note if person heard a snap or crack
Call 911 if: Bone is visible, limb is deformed, person cannot move the limb, injury involves head/neck/back/hip/pelvis, or severe pain
Control any bleeding: If open fracture, apply gentle pressure around (not on) protruding bone. Do not push bone back in
Immobilize the injury: Splint in position found. Include joint above and below fracture. Use rigid materials (boards, magazines) padded with cloth
Apply cold pack: Wrap ice in cloth, apply to injury for 20 minutes. Reduces swelling and pain. Never apply ice directly to skin
Elevate if possible: Raise injured limb above heart level only if it does not cause more pain. Helps reduce swelling
Monitor for shock: Watch for pale/clammy skin, rapid breathing, weakness. Keep person lying down and warm
Do not: Straighten the limb, allow person to eat/drink (may need surgery), or remove splint once applied

name: Sprain
description: Ligament injury from twisting or stretching

steps.text: Rest the injured area immediately
Apply ice for 20 minutes every 2-3 hours
Compress with elastic bandage but not too tight
Elevate the injured area above heart level
Take over-the-counter pain medication if needed
Seek medical care if unable to bear weight or severe swelling
Recognize a dislocation: Joint looks visibly deformed or out of place. Intense pain, inability to move joint, rapid swelling
Call 911: Especially for shoulder, hip, knee, or elbow dislocations. All dislocations need professional reduction
Do NOT attempt to relocate: Never try to pop the joint back in. This can cause permanent nerve, blood vessel, or tissue damage
Immobilize in position found: Use slings, pillows, or rolled blankets to support the joint exactly as you find it
Check circulation: Feel for pulse below injury. Check if fingers/toes are warm and can move. Numbness or cold indicates emergency
Apply cold pack: Wrap ice in cloth, apply around (not directly on) joint. Reduces pain and swelling. Apply for 20 minutes
Treat for shock: Keep person lying down and warm. Elevate legs if no spinal injury suspected
Do not allow eating or drinking: Surgery may be needed to reduce the dislocation

name: Head Injury
description: Trauma to the head requiring evaluation

steps.text: Call 911 if person is unconscious or severely injured
Keep person still - do not move neck
Apply gentle pressure to bleeding wounds with clean cloth
Monitor for vomiting, confusion, or unequal pupils
Do not give food, water, or medications
Keep person awake if possible and talking to you

name: Concussion
description: Mild traumatic brain injury from impact

steps.text: Remove from activity immediately
Monitor for danger signs: vomiting, confusion, unequal pupils
Have person rest in quiet, dim environment
Apply ice to any bumps
Wake person every 2-3 hours if sleeping to check responsiveness
Seek medical attention within 24 hours

name: Spinal Injury
description: Suspected spinal cord injury - do not move

steps.text: Call 911 immediately
Do not move the person under any circumstances
Stabilize head and neck with hands
Keep person calm and still
Monitor breathing and be ready for CPR
Cover with blanket to maintain body temperature
Call 911 immediately
Recognize signs: dizziness, pale skin, rapid pulse, tender abdomen
Keep person lying down with legs elevated
Do not give food or water
Keep person warm and calm
Monitor for shock and be ready for CPR

name: Embedded Object
description: Object stuck in body - do not remove

steps.text: Call 911 immediately
Do not remove the object
Stabilize object with bulky dressings around it
Control bleeding around the object
Keep person still and calm
Monitor for shock until help arrives
